34729602.review:
A relaxing, colourful 3D terrain-capture game with fabulous organisation of level structure, pretty graphics and VR support.

I usually associate hacking games with text and puzzles but this is nothing of the sort. It's a graphics-intensive point and click strategy game focused on capturing stuff and purchasing powerups.

"Levels" consist of an interconnected network of nodes which you have to strategically capture. The network surrounds you and although I don't have VR, I can imagine how impressive this would be viewed from a headset. There are different types and sizes of nodes. Some are 'Sentinels' that have extra firewall protection which you have to remove using special 'Hydra' tools which have to be purchased and have a single use. You can also purchase 'Exploits' which allow you to auto-capture an area, and later on Worms once you've unlocked them (I don't know what they do yet!) There is always a time limit for the level, and if you're too slow then you don't get paid and you lose some skill rating points, so the Exploits help to speed things up in order to beat the deadline.

The main objective of the level is to capture the big central 'Root' node. The reward for doing so is a set number of BTC, the main currency of the game, which allows you to purchase permanent powerups and unlocks to enable you to tackle more difficult nodes.

When you enter a node to capture it you see a 2D network with glowing virus points dotted around. You have to use your purple Viruses to infect certain nodes which then infect some of the surrounding network. There's a big yellow node in the centre of the network that you have to capture, but since you only have a limited number of Viruses it's usually necessary to make several attempts at it, or give up and try a different node. If you're successful you're rewarded with currency which you can use to purchase extra Viruses (these are multi-use and are the main tool) or single-use Hydras and Exploits. As you gain more and more Viruses this allows you to tackle the larger, more difficult nodes which give you more profit, more spending power and eventually get you closer to capturing the Root node.

90% of the time you spend capturing nodes (2D networks) and it becomes a tranquil, zen, repetitive experience - well for a while anyway, until the time limits of the more advanced levels start kicking in. I'm still not entirely sure if the virus spread is 100% logical or if there's a random element to it. I suspect the latter because I haven't been able to work out a specific rule about it, and viruses often spread further or less than expected. Generally speaking though, you do get a gut instinct about it after a while. I wouldn't call it a logical puzzle game, it's more about gradually gaining power and always trying to push the envelope.

I was pleasantly surprised to find a storyline of sorts depicted via reports on the main menu. It's a tale of corporate espionage and skulduggery, a nice distraction in between the main business of hacking nodes.

Overall organisation of the game is one of the most elegant I've ever seen. You use left-click to "zoom" into sub-networks and right-click to zoom out again to the main galaxy and settings/purchase menus. It's all wonderfully intuitive and smooth, and zapping through wormholes to your destination is pretty cool.

[h1]Performance[/h1]

I have a GTX 1050Ti. The game runs smoothly with no lag, and my fans blow at what I would consider to be medium pace. GTX 970 is the minimum and I would advise you to heed this if you intend to buy. The optimisation is pretty good but you do need a decent card.

[h1]Linux[/h1]

I usually frown on Unity games without native Linux support, but Darknet works flawlessly in wine so I'll turn a blind eye on this occasion. Still, why not port it, it's only a button click for the dev. I asked about it on their forum a month ago but no response at all.

[h1]Steam[/h1]

It was released a few weeks ago but still has no Steam features at all, which seems quite unusual. Never mind, it's not a deal-breaker in my opinion.

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]

Once again I'm extremely impressed with the way difficulty is handled. You go to the main 'cloud' of planets and incrementally increase or decrease the difficulty. Each time you do so a different system of worlds zooms up towards you. The higher the difficulty, the higher the BTC rewards. The difficulty of each world is represented as a percentage ranging from < 1% up to 50% and the BTC rewards match accordingly, from 1 BTC to 300! It shows you the percentages of what you 'stand to lose' and 'stand to gain' for your skill rating, although I'm not entirely sure how your skill rating fits into the picture at the moment.

Anyway, the point is that anyone can play this game, from a 10 year old child to a hardened puzzle/strategy expert and you can be very specific about how much challenge you want, depending on your mood at the time.

[h1]Value[/h1]

Although the scope/diversity of the game could be regarded as somewhat limited, the amount of content can't be faulted, there are tons of levels to keep you busy. There will inevitably be a lot of replay value as well, because once you get to the more difficult levels it's going to take multiple attempts to gain the BTC currency to increase your arsenal in order to tackle advanced levels.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

It's a game I'm likely to play often but in short doses. The 2D network capture can become repetitive after a while but the overall powerup system and progression makes it a game that will feed your lust for power over the long term, while at the same time keeping your adrenaline levels at zero in a relaxing atmosphere.

[code][h1][b]Полноценный обзор со скриншотами вы можете прочитать здесь:[/b] [url=https://dreamsofgenesisgaming.wordpress.com/2017/09/08/760/] Dreams of Genesis Gaming: Darknet[/url][/h1][/code]
[b]Darknet[/b] - простенькая и в то же время интересная стратегия-головоломка от разработчиков E McNeill. Нам предлагают погрузиться в киберпространство, и попробовать себя во взломе бесконечной виртуальной реальности Darknet.

Говоря про бесконечное пространство игры, я не преувеличивал. Многослойная система сложностей в целом, и многозадачность каждой отдельно взятой игры. Кто знает сколько там уровней и возможно ли вообще пройти ее полностью. Звучит сложно? Согласен, немного намудрил. Теперь попробую объяснить подробней, чтобы вы убедились: играть в неё сможет каждый.

Начну пожалуй с того, что аналогов ей я пока не встречал. Это вовсе не значит, что их нет, но лично мне строение Darknet было в новинку. Изначально делаем выбор нужной по сложности "системы". Ее сложность определяется в первую очередь временем. На взлом каждой дано определенное время, после его истечения вас "засекут". Если вы не успели взломать - игра потрачена. Соответственно, чем больше времени дано на взлом, тем легче система. А выглядит все примерно так: "погружаемся" в виртуальную реальность (визуальный эффект перемещения), перед нами появляется очень много систем (выглядящие, как планетки), смотрим на какую дано больше времени и начинаем с нее. Как только набираемся опыта и разбираемся, что к чему, повышаем уровень сложности и снова берем ту, где дано больше времени.

Это я рассказал о системе повышения сложностей, но сам геймплей мы почти не затронули. Теперь, когда мы выбрали систему, которую хотим взламывать, надо разобраться, как это собственно делается. Перед нами появляется множество связанным между собой желтых "планеток" (это лично мое сравнение) - система. Одни из них простые, другие окружены защитным полем, поясами, а в некоторых даже есть многоугольная хрень...ну короче, их там много разных. Чтобы захватить систему нужно взломать ее ядро (самая крупная и хитро-придуманная "планетка"). Чем больше прибамбасов вокруг и внутри планетки, тем она сложнее для взлома, но есть одна хитрость: гидра. Я не буду рассказывать подробно что, да как там нужно сделать. Это вас научит делать, и собственно покажет обучение в игре. Объяснить на пальцах не выйдет. Но будьте уверенны, обучение добротное, после полу часа в игре, вы уже скажете, что это как два пальца об асфальт. За взлом каждой планетки, выбранной системы, вы получите внутриигровую валюту, а за нее сможете покупать больше вирусов и гидр, для захвата. И вот так медленно, но верно (поначалу, позже разберетесь, и это будет происходить несколько быстрее) вы взломаете свою первую систему.

Графически рассчитана на то, что игрок будет играть в VR, но я играл без, и ощущения от этого не портились. Присутствуют визуальные эффекты погружения в "глубину" виртуальной реальности, и в целом обладает весьма приятной графикой. Звуковое оформление ненавязчивое и спокойное. Голос озвучки приятный, даром только, что нет русской локализации (ну как тут не возмутиться :D).

"Il ne paye pas de mine avec son nom générique, sa promesse de compatibilité VR et son look de jeu à clics mais objectivement, Darknet est une bonne surprise. Dans la peau d’un pirate, vous allez devoir collecter des nœuds d’informations dans plusieurs réseaux pour atteindre des sommes vertigineuses.  Vous devrez, via un petit jeu de puzzle très intelligent, acheter des virus et tenter de contaminer des points en espérant les voir atteindre le noyau du bloc d’info piraté avant d’être contré par un anti-virus alentours. Il faut alors être plus malin que le jeu et condamner quelques-uns de ces virus pour faire diversion.

Le jeu se rebelle rapidement avec des boucliers et autres fioritures : d’autres types d’objets à utiliser vous permettront de diminuer la force d’un nœud, de collecter tous les nœuds non-défendus aux alentours et autres bonus bienvenus. Rapidement, ce petit puzzle-game est très addictif.

Darknet n’a pas de fin, pas vraiment de scénario (même si quelques petites histoires sont proposées à la lecture) et se contente surtout d’être calme, tranquille, facile d’accès et relaxant. Entièrement traduit en français, voix comprises, il se permet donc une accessibilité pour tous vraiment salutaire. A chaque fin de partie, vous collecterez des points que vous pourrez dépenser dans des améliorations : davantage d’argent au début d’un piratage par exemple, histoire de rendre votre prochaine partie encore plus amusante.

On s’en lasse vite, mais Darknet fait très bien son boulot : amuser. On vous le conseille !"

This is a really good VR puzzle game. It seems quite complicated at first, but thanks to a very good tutorial, you'll find yourself hacking like a pro in no time. It is essentially puzzles within puzzles - you have one bigger web where your overall objective is to hack the central node, but in order to get to it, you'll have to take over other nodes around it. And each node is in itself a little puzzle to solve, where you're trying to place viruses to spread to the centre before the enemy defenses spread and wipe you out. While I think the game would work on a flat screen, the VR still feels quite nice and gives you that Hackerman/I'M IN THE INTERNET feel, especially with the dark backgrounds and the bright colours that really pop in VR. Overall, a really good game to play, with just the right amount of challenge, and a nice way to while away the time. I did a video review of the game as well.

32546076.review:
VR review (many reviews are for the monitor version)

Darknet, finally out of his timed exclusivity with Oculus, is now avaliable for SteamVR. It's a very peculiar boardgame with a simple but addictive gameplay, random levels, powerups and a potentially strong replayability and longevity. It's a niche product for strategy lovers: screenshots could be "scary" but represent well what Darknet is, a sort of hexagonal Reversi in cyberspace. From the tecnical point of view, this game was made to be played seated but today work properly in roomscale, even if you can't touch anything by hands, you use wands just to aim as a mouse cursor. 

Darknet is a good and polished product, I suggest it easily, but is not mainstream. And where is cool to see an huge board around you, virtual reality is not transforming the game in a whole new experience 10x as powerful as usual. Beware also for bugs, this first release has many issues with handtracking and user interface.

32409265.review:
Darknet is a strategy/puzzle game in which you play as an elite hacker in the internet. Your mission is to plug into cyberspace, and hack nodes to retrieve data, using viruses, worms, and exploits. There is an initial tutorial hack and as you progress in the game you have to steal the data before your signal gets traced and this is reflected in hacks with a time limit. There are therefore different difficulty levels, with hacking getting progressively difficult throughout the game. The game also offers you the option to save and continue a hack later. The design is simple but is perfect for this game giving you the immersed feeling of being inside the net, the game has a lot of depth and therefore appeals to those who enjoy puzzles or strategic gameplay. This is one of the best strategy games I have encountered in VR so far. The game also includes both VR and non-VR versions in the one purchase.

Hi! Sorry for the very late response; I only just saw this review.

I'm sorry you didn't enjoy the game, and I'm glad you were able to get a refund. Darknet was essentially made by a team of 1 person, so it's pretty limited in scope. I chose to focus on providing really deep gameplay, which worked great for some people, but if the gameplay just doesn't click, it just doesn't work. 

If you ever feel like trying again, I recommend picking a much more difficult level (you should have the option to do really difficult levels from the start; most people want a gentler ramp-up, but you might enjoy the extra challenge). If you're put off by the time limit, you can ignore it. The game won't reward your win, but if you pick a difficult level, it won't penalize you if you lose. No pressure! :)

32299724.review:
Ich habe Darknet kostenlos erhalten.

Es beschreibt sich als VR Spiel, ich aber habe es ohne VR gespielt, da ich keine besitze. Hat auch ohne super geklappt.
Darknet beschreibt sich als Puzzlespiel und dies kann ich total zustimmen. Man klickt sich in ein System, was man vorher auswählt und versucht dort seine Viren zu verbreiten. Dazu startet man einen oder mehrere Viren an einem blauen Punkt und von dort aus verbreiten sie sich. Kommt es zuerst an einen nächsten Punkt, statt in die Mitte zum Kern, so schaltet sich die Firewall ein und beseitigt den Virus. 

Hier heisst es also Nachdenken wie man es am besten lösen kann. Das Spiel erinnert mich sehr an das Windows Spiel Minesweeper, wer es noch kennt^^ 

Durch erfolgreiches Hacken bekommt man immer etwas Geld, womit man sich neue Viren oder ähnliche Technologie kaufen kann, die einem das Spiel einfacher machen. 

Das Ziel von jeder Mission ist es die Stammzelle erfolgreich zu hacken, davor muss man natürlich die kleineren Zellen hacken. Hat man dies geschafft kriegt man Punkte, die man wieder ausgeben kann.

Ich denke, das Spiel hat eine gesamte Spielzeit von so ca. 5-10 Stunden. Denke für die Puzzleafinen könnte sich der Preis schon echt lohnen. Dennoch ist es immer wieder das Gleiche und man hat nur wenig Abwechslung. Sprachausgabe sowie die Texte haben keine Übersetzungsfehler und Bugs sind mir auch nicht vorgekommen.

Eine eher gemischte Kaufempfehlung :/

32277960.review:
[h1]Darknet - [i]This simple looking yet awesomely addictive puzzle game is now on the Vive![/i][/h1]
Part of me already wants to stop writing and load it up again, no you temptress of a game i will not submit to your siren call! 
At first glance you have what appears to be a basic little puzzle game but as you play you will discover there is a ton of strategy here, from working out what antivirus nodes to tactfully pluck off to allow your final assault to succeed, to setting up the enemy nodes in preparation for that oh so satisfying hydra attack that topples the enemy nodes like a giant wave of oh yes!
This is a game i can see myself playing a lot!
The actual “hacking” takes place by injecting an antivirus node with your virus, this then spreads out until it hits another antivirus or the core, in the former case the node you used and the one it hit are used up and the antivirus spreads over your virus. Once those nodes are used up you can place any other viruses you have in the remaining ones, allowing for some very good strategic thinking. Your goal is to infect the core.
 
[b]ROOMSCALE / ENVIRONMENT[/b] 
The environments are by design basic, but they are also done very well, i love the feeling of having your head in the node and this is pretty much how i imagine cyberspace to be.
 
[b]GRAPHICS[/b] 
Again somewhat minimalistic by design but they all fit perfectly and the animations are cool, i have no complaints here at all.
 
[b]PERFORMANCE[/b] 
The only issue i had was very very rarely the playspace rotated, this may of been down to me? But other than that no issues at all
 
[b]INTUITIVENESS[/b] 
You get a tutorial that is very well done and it is not long before you are playing it as though you have played it your whole life. Very cleverly done in game.
The menus can feel a bit overwhelming though, there is a panel for advanced users that is not explained (easter egg?) and ingame  if you look behind you in a node you see a keypad...i have yet to figure out what it is for beyond there is clearly a code
 
[b]PROS:[/b] 
[list]
[*] Amazingly addictive.
[*] Way more fun than it has any right to be.
[*] Great atmosphere (from a Lawnmower man / tron image of cyberspace...may be showing my age)
[*] Plenty of replayability and permanent unlocks to be bought with your digital spoils.
[*] For those unfortunate enough to not have a vr headset it does work on the standard mouse monitor system.
[/list]
 
[b]CONS:[/b] 
[list]
[*] I can not really think of any.
[/list]
 
[b]The first try video:[/b]
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wn3OiyJKtLM
 
[b]VERDICT[/b] 
This is a very very good game, if you like strategy games it really is a no brainer. You will certainly get your money's worth here!
It is one of those games that if you own VR you should also own this.
